questions.title: Interest Rate Risk and Returns
questions.question:
A long-term bond investor with an investment horizon of 8 years invests in option-free, fixed-rate bonds with a Macaulay duration of 10.5. The investor most likely currently has a:

  1. positive duration gap and is currently exposed to the risk of lower interest rates.
  2. positive duration gap and is currently exposed to the risk of higher interest rates.
  3. negative duration gap and is currently exposed to the risk of higher interest rates.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because while the duration gap is positive the investor is currently exposed to the risk of higher, not lower, interest rates. Correct. The duration gap is the bond‚Äôs Macaulay duration minus the investment horizon, which is positive in this case. A positive duration gap implies that the investor is currently exposed to the risk of higher interest rates. Incorrect because the duration gap is positive, not negative, implying that the investor is currently exposed to the risk of higher interest rates. Interest Rate Risk and Return describe the relationships among a bond‚Äôs holding period return, its Macaulay duration, and the investment horizon;
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because while the duration gap is positive the investor is currently exposed to the risk of higher, not lower, interest rates.

  2. Correct. The duration gap is the bond‚Äôs Macaulay duration minus the investment horizon, which is positive in this case. A positive duration gap implies that the investor is currently exposed to the risk of higher interest rates.

  3. Incorrect because the duration gap is positive, not negative, implying that the investor is currently exposed to the risk of higher interest rates.

questions.title: Interest Rate Risk and Returns
questions.question: Assuming no capital gain or loss when the bond is sold, an investor‚Äôs horizon yield is equal to a bond‚Äôs yield-to-maturity at the time of investment if coupons are reinvested at a rate:

choices.A: lower than the bond‚Äôs yield-to-maturity at investment.
choices.B: equal to the bond‚Äôs yield-to-maturity at investment.
choices.C: higher than the bond‚Äôs yield-to-maturity at investment.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. For the horizon yield to match the original yield-to-maturity of the bond, two conditions must be met: (1) The coupon payments are reinvested at the original yield-to-maturity. (2) The bond is sold at the constant-yield price trajectory, implying no capital gain or loss when the bond is sold. Since there is no gain or loss when the bond is sold, the horizon yield will be equal to the yield-to-maturity if the first condition is met (i.e., the coupons are reinvested at the original yield-to-maturity). A is incorrect because the horizon yield will be lower than the yield-to-maturity if the coupons are reinvested at a lower rate than the original yield-to-maturity, assuming no capital gain or loss on sale of the bond. C is incorrect because the horizon yield will be higher than the yield-to-maturity if the coupons are reinvested at a higher rate than the original yield-to-maturity, assuming no capital gain or loss on sale of the bond.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. For the horizon yield to match the original yield-to-maturity of the bond, two conditions must be met:

(1) The coupon payments are reinvested at the original yield-to-maturity.

(2) The bond is sold at the constant-yield price trajectory, implying no capital gain or loss when the bond is sold.

Since there is no gain or loss when the bond is sold, the horizon yield will be equal to the yield-to-maturity if the first condition is met (i.e., the coupons are reinvested at the original yield-to-maturity).

A is incorrect because the horizon yield will be lower than the yield-to-maturity if the coupons are reinvested at a lower rate than the original yield-to-maturity, assuming no capital gain or loss on sale of the bond.

C is incorrect because the horizon yield will be higher than the yield-to-maturity if the coupons are reinvested at a higher rate than the original yield-to-maturity, assuming no capital gain or loss on sale of the bond.

questions.title: Interest Rate Risk and Returns
questions.question:
When a bond investor‚Äôs coupon reinvestment risk dominates market price risk, the investor‚Äôs investment horizon must be:

  1. less than the Macaulay duration of the bond.
  2. equal to the Macaulay duration of the bond.
  3. greater than the Macaulay duration of the bond.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because when the investment horizon is less than the Macaulay duration of the bond, market price risk dominates coupon reinvestment risk and the investor is at risk of higher interest rates. Incorrect because when the investment horizon is equal to the Macaulay duration of the bond, coupon reinvestment risk offsets market price risk. Correct. When the investment horizon is greater than the Macaulay duration of the bond, coupon reinvestment risk dominates market price risk and the investor is at risk of lower interest rates. Interest Rate Risk and Return describe the relationships among a bond‚Äôs holding period return, its Macaulay duration, and the investment horizon;
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because when the investment horizon is less than the Macaulay duration of the bond, market price risk dominates coupon reinvestment risk and the investor is at risk of higher interest rates.

  2. Incorrect because when the investment horizon is equal to the Macaulay duration of the bond, coupon reinvestment risk offsets market price risk.

  3. Correct. When the investment horizon is greater than the Macaulay duration of the bond, coupon reinvestment risk dominates market price risk and the investor is at risk of lower interest rates.

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. A bond purchased at a discount will have its price ‚Äúpulled to par‚Äù as it approaches maturity. Its carrying value at time t is equal to its purchase price plus the accumulated discount amortization. A is incorrect because a bond purchased below par is purchased at a discount, not a premium. B is incorrect because the accumulated discount amortization is added, not subtracted, from the purchase price to calculate carrying value.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. A bond purchased at a discount will have its price ‚Äúpulled to par‚Äù as it approaches maturity. Its carrying value at time t is equal to its purchase price plus the accumulated discount amortization.

A is incorrect because a bond purchased below par is purchased at a discount, not a premium.

B is incorrect because the accumulated discount amortization is added, not subtracted, from the purchase price to calculate carrying value.

questions.title: Interest Rate Risk and Returns
questions.question:
The weighted average number of years to receipt of the principal and interest payments that will result in realization of the initial market discount rate on a bond is best described as:

  1. effective duration.
  2. modified duration.
  3. Macaulay duration.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because effective duration is a measure of the sensitivity of the bond‚Äôs price (expressed as a percentage change) to a change in the benchmark yield curve. Incorrect because modified duration provides an estimate of a bond‚Äôs percentage price change given a change in its yield to maturity (rather than a measure expressed as a weighted average period of years). Correct. Macaulay duration is a weighted average of the time to receipt (expressed in years) of a bond‚Äôs promised payments where the weights are the shares of the full price that correspond to each of the bond‚Äôs promised future payments. This weighted average results in the realization of the bond‚Äôs initial market discount rate. Interest Rate Risk and Return define, calculate, and interpret Macaulay duration.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because effective duration is a measure of the sensitivity of the bond‚Äôs price (expressed as a percentage change) to a change in the benchmark yield curve.

  2. Incorrect because modified duration provides an estimate of a bond‚Äôs percentage price change given a change in its yield to maturity (rather than a measure expressed as a weighted average period of years).

  3. Correct. Macaulay duration is a weighted average of the time to receipt (expressed in years) of a bond‚Äôs promised payments where the weights are the shares of the full price that correspond to each of the bond‚Äôs promised future payments. This weighted average results in the realization of the bond‚Äôs initial market discount rate.

questions.title: Interest Rate Risk and Returns
questions.question: The duration gap at which reinvestment risk and price risk are equal is:
questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. Reinvestment risk and price risk equally offset each other when an investor‚Äôs investment horizon equals a bond‚Äôs Macaulay duration. This is when the duration gap is zero. A is incorrect because a duration gap of less than zero means that Macaulay duration is less than the investor‚Äôs investment horizon and that reinvestment risk is higher than price risk. C is incorrect because when the duration gap is greater than zero, the Macaulay duration is greater than the investor‚Äôs investment horizon, so price risk is higher than reinvestment risk.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. Reinvestment risk and price risk equally offset each other when an investor‚Äôs investment horizon equals a bond‚Äôs Macaulay duration. This is when the duration gap is zero.

A is incorrect because a duration gap of less than zero means that Macaulay duration is less than the investor‚Äôs investment horizon and that reinvestment risk is higher than price risk.

C is incorrect because when the duration gap is greater than zero, the Macaulay duration is greater than the investor‚Äôs investment horizon, so price risk is higher than reinvestment risk.

questions.title: Interest Rate Risk and Returns
questions.question:
Which of the following statements regarding the interest rate risk of a fixed-rate bond is correct?

  1. Coupon reinvestment risk and market price risk are positively related.
  2. All investors in a particular bond are exposed to the same interest rate risk.
  3. Market price risk matters more than coupon reinvestment risk when the investor‚Äôs time horizon is short relative to the bond‚Äôs time to maturity.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because coupon reinvestment risk and market price risk are offsetting types of interest rate risk that are inversely (not positively) related. When interest rates go up (down), the future value of reinvested coupons increases (decreases) whereas the sale price of a bond that matures after the horizon date decreases (increases). Incorrect because investors holding the same bond can have very different exposures to interest rate risk if they have different investment horizons. When the investor‚Äôs horizon is short relative to a bond‚Äôs time to maturity, market price risk matters more than coupon reinvestment risk. In contrast, when the investor‚Äôs horizon is long, reinvestment risk matters more than market price risk. Correct. Market price risk matters more than coupon reinvestment risk when the investor has a short horizon relative to the bond‚Äôs time to maturity. Interest Rate Risk and Return calculate and interpret the sources of return from investing in a fixed-rate bond;
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because coupon reinvestment risk and market price risk are offsetting types of interest rate risk that are inversely (not positively) related. When interest rates go up (down), the future value of reinvested coupons increases (decreases) whereas the sale price of a bond that matures after the horizon date decreases (increases).

  2. Incorrect because investors holding the same bond can have very different exposures to interest rate risk if they have different investment horizons. When the investor‚Äôs horizon is short relative to a bond‚Äôs time to maturity, market price risk matters more than coupon reinvestment risk. In contrast, when the investor‚Äôs horizon is long, reinvestment risk matters more than market price risk.

  3. Correct. Market price risk matters more than coupon reinvestment risk when the investor has a short horizon relative to the bond‚Äôs time to maturity.

questions.question: Hightest Capital purchases a seven-year, 6.4% coupon bond and has an intended investment horizon of four years. The Macaulay duration of the bond is 5.86 years. If interest rates increase by 50 bps immediately after buying the bond, Hightest Capital faces:
questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. Hightest Capital‚Äôs investment horizon is four years, which is less than the bond‚Äôs Macaulay duration of 5.86 years. Therefore, price risk dominates reinvestment risk and Hightest Capital faces price risk from rising interest rates. B is incorrect because the increase in interest rates is beneficial for coupon reinvestment. Therefore, Hightest Capital has positive reinvestment risk. C is incorrect because Hightest Capital faces the risk that the price of the bond will fall as a result of the 50 bp increase in interest rates and therefore has negative price risk.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. Hightest Capital‚Äôs investment horizon is four years, which is less than the bond‚Äôs Macaulay duration of 5.86 years. Therefore, price risk dominates reinvestment risk and Hightest Capital faces price risk from rising interest rates.

B is incorrect because the increase in interest rates is beneficial for coupon reinvestment. Therefore, Hightest Capital has positive reinvestment risk.

C is incorrect because Hightest Capital faces the risk that the price of the bond will fall as a result of the 50 bp increase in interest rates and therefore has negative price risk.
